Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of a Question Prompt List Intervention for Older Patients Considering Major Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised clinical trial used a stepped-wedge design

Participants.evidence: Participants were 60 years or older with at least one comorbidity and an oncologic or vascular problem treatable with major surgery.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare the effectiveness of a question prompt list (QPL) intervention versus usual care on patient engagement and well-being among older patients considering major surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Primary outcomes were the number and type of questions asked during the surgical visit and patient-reported Perceived Efficacy in Patient-Physician Interactions scale.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The difference in MYCaW scores for family members was greater in usual care (effect estimate, 1.51; 95% CI, 0.28-2.74; P=.008).
